isis.stitle: VT 275 Engine Diagnostics Manual - Hard Start and No Start Diagnostics - Test Procedures - 13. Low ICP System Pressure

svcprocinfo.para: PurposeTo determine the cause of low injection control pressure that prevents engine starting

item.para: EST with MasterDiagnostics® software
EZ-Tech® interface cable
DMM
Actuator Breakout Harness
Pressure Sensor Breakout Harness
Crankcase Pressure Test Adapter
ICP System Test Adapter
ICP Adapter/Plug Kit
- ICP Sensor Adapter
- ICP Leak Test Plug
Oil fill extension
Compressed air source 689 kPa (100 psi)

warning.para: To avoid personal injury, death, including damage to the engine or vehicle, read all safety instructions in the "Safety Information" section of this manual.

note.para: Do the following procedures in sequence or test results will be incorrect.

svcprocinfo.para: Before starting " Test 13.1. System Function " make sure the engine lubrication system will build oil pressure, while the engine is cranking.
Continue Test 13.1., if terminals on the IPR valve and engine harness are not damaged or corroded.

figure.caption: IPR valve coil in weather protected position

step1.para: Rotate IPR valve coil counterclockwise 90 degrees. Do not loosen valve. (Tools are not required.)

note.para: After repairs are made, return IPR valve coil to weather protected position as shown above.

step1.para: Disconnect engine wiring harness from IPR valve and inspect engine wiring harness connector and IPR valve terminal for corrosion. Inspect for bent pins, or pushed back pins.

item.para: If there is corrosion on either the IPR valve or the wiring harness connector for the IPR valve, be sure to replace both the IPR valve and wiring harness connector for the IPR valve. Retest ICP pressure.
If the wiring harness connector and IPR valve are not corroded or damaged, continue with step 3.

step1.para: Connect Actuator Breakout Harness to the IPR valve.

note.para: Do not connect the engine wiring harness to the Actuator Breakout Harness.

caution.para: If the engine harness is connected to the Actuator Breakout Harness, the ignition switch fuse will blow or cause damage to wiring harness.

figure.caption: Actuator Breakout Harness, power, and ground from alternator

step1.para: Apply B+ volts and ground to the IPR valve.

caution.para: Do not leave IPR valve energized longer than 120 seconds. This can damage the IPR valve.

warning.para: To avoid personal injury, death, including damage to the engine or vehicle, understand and comply with the following:
While cranking the engine, the engine could start.
Before cranking the engine do the following:

item.para: Set parking brake.
Shift transmission to park or neutral.
Block wheels.

step1.para: Crank the engine and monitor ICP pressure using the EST or DMM and Pressure Sensor Breakout Harness.
Record results on Diagnostic Form.

item.para: If ICP increases above 3.45 MPa (500 psi) (0.82 volts), the mechanical system is operating correctly for the engine to start. Do not continue with ICP system diagnostics.
Check DTCs recorded during test 4. (Make sure problems were corrected.)

For problems in the electrical circuit, see " IPR (Injection Pressure Regulator)
" in the " Electronic Control Systems Diagnostics
" section of this manual.
If 3.45 MPa (500 psi) (0.82 volts ) can not be reached, continue with " Test 13.2. IPR Function ."

note.para: Before doing this test, inspect O-ring on the ICP System Test Adapter. Replace O-ring, if worn, cracked or cut.

figure.caption: Shop air supply and oil fill stand tube (right side of engine)

step1.para: Remove the oil fill cap from valve cover.
Insert oil fill extension into valve cover.
Insert Crankcase Pressure Test Adapter into oil fill extension.

note.para: The Crankcase Pressure Test Adapter will magnify the sound of an air leak.

step1.para: Disconnect engine harness from ICP sensor.
Remove ICP sensor from the right oil rail.

figure.caption: ICP System Test Adapter

step1.para: Install the ICP System Test Adapter.
Assemble a test hose, shutoff valve, and air chuck; connect air chuck to the ICP System Test Adapter.
Connect the shop air supply line to test hose. Make sure the shutoff valve is closed.
Apply 689 kPa (100 psi) of pressure, open shutoff valve, and use Crankcase Pressure Test Adapter to listen for an air leak.

note.para: When air pressure is applied for the first time, it may take up to 5 minutes before an air leak can be heard. This allows air pressure to displace the engine oil in the ICP system. Once engine oil is displaced, an air leak can be heard almost immediately.

item.para: A faint air leak should be heard. Air should be passing through the IPR valve and returning to the crankcase when the IPR valve is not energized.

step1.para: Record the results on Diagnostic Form.

Connect the Actuator Breakout Harness to the IPR valve and apply B+ and ground. (Shop air supply should still be applied to the ICP system.) Use Crankcase Pressure Test Adapter to listen for an air leak.

caution.para: Do not leave IPR valve energized longer than 120 seconds. This can damage the IPR valve.

step1.para: Record results on Diagnostic Form.

item.para: When the IPR valve is energized, the air leak should stop.
If a faint air leak is still heard, replace the IPR valve. Follow the procedures in the Engine Service Manual. Repeat step 11 to verify if the IPR valve is functioning correctly.
If a leak is still heard after replacing the IPR valve, continue with " 13.3. Under Valve Cover Leaks ."
If an air leak is not heard when the IPR valve is energized, continue with " 13.5. High-pressure Pump ." This test result indicates no leaks in the high-pressure oil system.

note.para: Before doing this test, inspect the D-rings for the ICP Sensor Adapter and ICP Leak Test Plug. Replace D-rings if worn, cracked or cut.

step1.para: Close shutoff valve in test hose before disconnecting shop air.
Remove test hose.
Remove the left and right valve covers. Follow the procedures in the Engine Service Manual.

note.para: This will help you hear where the leak is coming from.

figure.caption: ICP System Test Adapter with test hose (right cylinder head)

step1.para: Reconnect test hose and ICP System Test Adapter.
Connect the shop air supply line to test hose. Make sure the shutoff valve is closed.
Apply 689 kPa (100 psi) of pressure, open shutoff valve, and listen for an air leak.

item.para: A faint air leak should be heard. Air should be passing through the IPR valve and returning to the crankcase when the IPR valve is not energized.

step1.para: Use the Actuator Breakout Harness to apply B+ and ground to the IPR valve.

caution.para: Do not leave IPR valve energized longer than 120 seconds. This can damage the IPR valve.

step1.para: Record results on Diagnostic Form.

item.para: Repair any defects found in the area under the valve covers. If more detailed instructions are needed to isolate a leak in the oil rail area, see " 13.4. Cylinder Head Isolation ." Retest after repairs to verify mechanical operation of the ICP system.
If leaks are not detected in areas under the valve covers, but air leaks are coming from the crankcase, continue with step 9.

step1.para: Remove test hose and ICP System Test Adapter from right oil rail.
Install the ICP sensor into right oil rail.

figure.caption: ICP Adapter/Plug Kit

calloutgroup.callout1: ICP Leak Test Plug (Solid hex head)

figure.caption: Case-to-head tube plug and ICP Leak Test Plug

step1.para: Remove the case-to-head tube plug in the rear of right side oil rail and install the ICP Sensor Adapter in this port.

note.para: Understand and comply with the following:

item.para: This will block air flow to the right oil rail and injectors.
When case-to-head tube plug is removed, the case-to-head tube may be still attached. Remove tube from plug. A new case-to-head tube assembly must be installed, to leak test plug or sensor adapter.
If case-to-head tube plug has a square drive, the replacement case-to-head tube is no longer supported. A case-to-head tube with a hex drive in the plug must be used as a replacement.
Both the left and right side case-to-head tubes and plugs must be replaced.
If the wrong diagnostic tool is used, a misdiagnosis will result. If the case-to-head tube plug has a hex drive in the head, use ICP Adapter/Plug Kit (ZTSE4690) only.

figure.caption: ICP Sensor Adapter with test hose

step1.para: Connect test hose and ICP System Test Adapter to ICP Sensor Adapter.
Remove the case-to-head tube plug from the rear of the left side oil rail. Install the ICP Leak Test Plug in this port.

note.para: Understand and comply with the following:

item.para: This will block air flow to the left oil rail and injectors.
When case-to-head tube plug is removed, the case-to-head tube may be still attached. Remove tube from plug. A new case-to-head tube assembly must be installed, to leak test plug or sensor adapter.
If case-to-head tube plug has a square drive, the replacement case-to-head tube is no longer supported. A case-to-head tube with a hex drive in the plug must be used as a replacement.
Both the left and right side case-to-head tubes and plugs must be replaced.
If the wrong diagnostic tool is used, a misdiagnosis will result. If the case-to-head tube plug has a hex drive in the head, use ICP Adapter/Plug Kit (ZTSE4690) only.

step1.para: Connect shop air to test hose in right side. Make sure the shutoff valve is closed.
Apply 689 kPa (100 psi) of pressure, open shutoff valve, and listen for an air leak.

item.para: A faint air leak should be heard. Air should be passing through the IPR valve and returning to the crankcase when the IPR valve is not energized.

step1.para: Use the Actuator Breakout Harness to apply B+ and ground to the IPR valve.

caution.para: Do not leave IPR valve energized longer than 120 seconds. This can damage the IPR valve.

step1.para: Listen for an air leak.

item.para: If an air leak is heard coming from the crankcase, continue with step 18.
If an air leak is not heard, one or more injector O-rings or oil rail O-rings are the cause of leak. If unable to tell which side is leaking, do " 13.4. Cylinder Head Isolation ."

step1.para: Disconnect the shop air supply from test hose.

figure.caption: Case-to-head tube plug and case-to-head tube

step1.para: Remove and replace questionable case-to-head tube or tubes. Follow procedures in the Engine Service Manual.

figure.caption: Case-to-head tube and Case-To-Head Tube Removal Tool

note.para: If case-to-head tube is not attached to the leak test plug or sensor adapter, use Case-To-Head Tube Removal Tool (ZTSE4694) to remove tube from crankcase.
If the leak test plug has a square drive in the head, both side case-to-head tubes, plugs, and adapters must be replaced.

figure.caption: High-pressure pump cover

step1.para: Remove the high-pressure pump cover. Follow procedures in the Engine Service manual .
Connect the shop air supply line to the ICP system test adapter. Make sure the shutoff valve is closed.

item.para: Apply 689 kPa (100 psi) of pressure, open shutoff valve, and listen for an air leak.
A faint air leak should be heard. Air should be passing through the IPR valve and returning to the crankcase when the IPR valve is not energized.

step1.para: Use the Actuator Breakout Harness to apply B+ and ground to the IPR valve.

caution.para: Do not leave IPR valve energized longer than 120 seconds. This can damage the IPR valve.

figure.caption: Possible leak areas in Branch Tube Connection to the discharge port of high-pressure pump
Possible leak areas in Branch Tube Assembly

step1.para: Check for air leaks in the Branch Tube Assembly connection to the discharge port of high-pressure pump and the Branch Tube Adapter.

figure.caption: Possible leak areas under high-pressure pump

step1.para: Listen for air leaks in both O-ring areas under the high-pressure pump,

item.para: If an air leak is not detected in the area under the high-pressure cover, but an air leak is heard, replace the Branch Tube Assembly.
If an air leak is located or detected, repair or replace as required.

svcsubproc.title: 13.4. Cylinder Head Isolation

note.para: Before doing this test, inspect the D-rings for the ICP Leak Test Plug. Replace D-rings if worn, cracked or cut.

svcsubproc.para: Depending on which rail is being tested, the complete test setup must be on the same side.

figure.caption: ICP Leak Test Plug and ICP System Test Adapter (right cylinder head)
ICP Leak Test Plug and ICP System Test Adapter (left cylinder head)

step1.para: Remove the case-to-head tube plug from the rear of the oil rail. Install the ICP Leak Test Plug in this port.

note.para: Understand and comply with the following:

item.para: This will block air flow to the oil rail and injectors.
When case-to-head tube plug is removed, the case-to-head tube may be still attached. Remove tube from plug. A new case-to-head tube assembly must be installed, to leak test plug or sensor adapter.
If case-to-head tube plug has a square drive, the replacement case-to-head tube is no longer supported. A case-to-head tube with a hex drive in the plug must be used as a replacement.
Both the left and right side case-to-head tubes and plugs must be replaced.
If the wrong diagnostic tool is used, a misdiagnosis will result. If the case-to-head tube plug has a hex drive in the head, use ICP Adapter/Plug Kit (ZTSE4690) only.

step1.para: Install ICP System Test Adapter into ICP sensor port.

item.para: ICP sensor removed from right cylinder head
Plug removed from left cylinder head

step1.para: Connect the shop air supply line to the ICP System Test Adapter. Make sure the shutoff valve is closed.
Apply 689 kPa (100 psi) of pressure, open shutoff valve, and listen for an air leak.

note.para: When air pressure is applied for the first time, it may take up to 5 minutes before the leak can be heard. This allows the air pressure to displace the engine oil in the ICP system. Once the engine oil is displaced, an air leak should be heard almost immediately after applying air pressure.

step1.para: Record results on Diagnostic Form

item.para: If an air leak is not detected, the air leak may be coming from the crankcase or opposite cylinder head. Verify previous test results and repeat procedure for opposite cylinder head.
If an air leak is detected, repair as needed and verify the integrity of the repairs.

note.para: Do this test only if Test 13.2 did not have leaks and Test 6 had low ICP.
Before doing this test, inspect the D-rings for the ICP Sensor Adapter and ICP Leak Test Plug. Replace D-rings if worn, cracked or cut.

step1.para: Close shutoff valve in test hose before disconnecting shop air.
Remove test hose.
Remove the left and right valve covers, following procedures in the Engine Service Manual.

figure.caption: ICP Adapter/Plug Kit

calloutgroup.callout1: ICP Leak Test Plug (Solid hex head)

figure.caption: Case-to-head tube plug and ICP Leak Test Plug

step1.para: Remove the case-to-head tube plug in the rear of right side oil rail and install the ICP Sensor Adapter in this port.

note.para: Understand and comply with the following:

item.para: This will block oil flow to the right oil rail and injectors.
When case-to-head tube plug is removed, the case-to-head tube may be still attached. Remove tube from plug. A new case-to-head tube assembly must be installed, to leak test plug or sensor adapter.
If case-to-head tube plug has a square drive, the replacement case-to-head tube is no longer supported. A case-to-head tube with a hex drive in the plug must be used as a replacement.
Both the left and right side case-to-head tubes and plugs must replaced.
If the wrong diagnostic tool is used, a misdiagnosis will result. If the case-to-head tube plug has a hex drive in the head, use ICP Adapter/Plug Kit (ZTSE4690) only.

figure.caption: ICP sensor with ICP Sensor Adapter (right cylinder head)

step1.para: Install ICP sensor into ICP Sensor Adapter.
Connect the engine wiring harness to the ICP sensor. Use the Pressure Sensor Breakout Harness as an extension, if needed.

figure.caption: ICP Leak Test Plug (left cylinder head)

step1.para: Remove the case-to-head tube plug from the rear of the left side oil rail. Install the ICP Leak Test Plug in this port.

note.para: Understand and comply with the following:

item.para: This will block oil flow to the left oil rail and injectors.
When case-to-head tube plug is removed, the case-to-head tube may be still attached. Remove tube from plug. A new case-to-head tube assembly must be installed, to leak test plug or sensor adapter.
If case-to-head tube plug has a square drive, the replacement case-to-head tube is no longer supported. A case-to-head tube with a hex drive in the plug must be used as a replacement.
Both the left and right side case-to-head tubes and plugs must be replaced.
If the wrong diagnostic tool is used, a misdiagnosis will result. If the case-to-head tube plug has a hex drive in the head, use ICP Adapter/Plug Kit (ZTSE4690) only.

note.para: This blocks oil flow to both rails and all injectors; only the branch tube assembly, case-to-head tube, and the high-pressure pump will be tested.

step1.para: Use the Actuator Breakout Harness to apply B+ and ground to the IPR valve.

caution.para: Do not leave IPR valve energized longer than 120 seconds. This can damage the IPR valve.

step1.para: Crank the engine and monitor ICP pressure.
Record results on Diagnostic Form.

item.para: If unable to build the ICP pressure above 3.45 MPa (500 psi) (0.82 volts), check branch tube, case-to-head tubes use of proper diagnostic tools or faulty high pressure pump. Follow the procedure in the Engine Service Manual. Retest to verify repairs.

If able to build ICP pressure above 3.45 MPa (500 psi) (0.82 volts), check previous test results. Remove the ICP Leak Test Plug from the left side oil rail and re-install case-to-head-tube plug. Continue with step 11.

caution.para: To prevent engine damage, we recommend replacing case-to-head tubes each time they are removed. The D-rings are not replaceable. Inspect each D-ring carefully for cuts, abrasion, and twisting; do not reuse a case-to-head tube having any of these conditions

step1.para: Crank the engine and monitor the ICP pressure (right side isolation).

item.para: If unable to build ICP pressure above 3.45 MPa (500 psi) (0.82 volts), the problem is on left side. Do " Test 13.4. Cylinder Head Isolation " and check for leaks.

If able to build ICP pressure above 3.45 MPa (500 psi) (0.82 volts), remove ICP Test Adapter from right side oil rail and re-install case-to-head-tube plug. Re-install ICP sensor. Reconnect ICP sensor to engine wiring harness. Continue with step 12.

step1.para: Crank the engine and monitor ICP pressure.

item.para: If unable to build the ICP pressure above 3.45 MPa (500 psi) (0.82 volts), the problem is on the right side. Do " 13.4. Cylinder Head Isolation" and check for leaks.
If able to build pressure the engine should start and run. Install valve covers, following procedures in the Engine Service Manual.
